posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: My current goal before the season is to learn about robot vision and how to use april tags and such, I was wondering if there was any way to make a program that detects the april tags using wpilib vs code that uses my laptop camera instead of any camera on a robot?

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: PhotonVision will run in your laptop. You can interface with the Network Tables with Python scripts

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: But I‚Äôm not using Python, does that matter?

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: You can also run in simulation mode in vs code, it should do everything as well. Sorry I forgot to mention that. That‚Äôs also every language

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
If you want something that might run out-of-the-box in simulation (I haven‚Äôt tried it) and lets you see one way to implement vision and then experiment with it, you might want to check out the swerve and vision template from team 1218 .  This code is in Java and has simulation classes for both drive and vision.

You may still want to use your laptop camera with PhotonVision to get some experience with making a real camera work.  Be sure to get the right version for your laptop (win, mac, or linux). Experience the ‚Äúfun‚Äù of calibrating your camera for 3D pose estimation.  See how the exposure and brightness settings impact tag recognition.  See how different camera resolutions impact frame rate and range at which you can detect tags.

link_counts.title: GitHub - VulcanRobotics/1218Swerve: Swerve drive using AdvantageKit, custom photonvision system, and helpful drive commands.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
There are serval method to get this done.

You could run robot code under simulation. Using the built in simulation of WPILib this will give you a (mostly) simulated roborio which would also act like a NetworkTables server. You than could have your vision platform (photonvision, limelight, custom solution, etc) connect to this simulated robot and you could look into the NetworkTables variable being passed to your robot code.

For a more simplified setup, Glass could be used as a NetworkTables server so your vision software could connect to connect to.

Of course you need the actual environment to run your vision software. For photonvision they do support Running it on a windows PC or Mac . For any custom code, It‚Äôs all up to you to choose the environment and stack to use. Speaking of that, WPILib simulation and Glass do run on Linux. If I am testing a CUDA + YOLO based custom object detection program, I could install Ubuntu on my computer, train and test my model using the powerful GPU I have and make my vision software interface with NetworkTables on the simulator before I port this software to my Jetson coprocessor.

You could also have a coprocessor (raspberry pi, for example) connect to your computer (As long as they are under the same network) simulated robot or glass If you have the resource lying around.

Also, my personal suggestion, Get the same camera that you will be using on the robot and code & test it on your laptop. This will makes things much easier such as the calibration.

link_counts.title: Introduction to Robot Simulation ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
If you want to take a peek inside the ‚Äúblack box‚Äù of PhotonVision or LimeLight you can see a little of the calculations being done with this ‚Äúpure‚Äù WPILib program that runs on a roboRIO or simulated using VSCode and some USB camera - built-in or plugged in. It has the pose calculations added to the WPILib AprilTag example that has some OpenCV drawing for fun.

It has a reference to LL which you can copy the nearby class or just comment out a few lines of code. The CameraServer.startAutomaticCapture() picks up a camera - usually the first one is your laptop built-in camera (black image if your laptop cover is closed). You control which camera is used with a parameter such as CameraServer.startAutomaticCapture(1) . Open a browser in 127.0.0.1:1181 and 127.0.0.1:1182 to see the camera image and interpreted AprilTag view.
